entry.title: Joaquin Phoenix‚Äôs Joker sequel planned for release in October 2024
entry.summary:
Joaquin Phoenix in Joker. | Screenshot: Joker
The sequel to 2019‚Äôs Oscar-winning Joker is planned for release on October 4th 2024, Deadline reports. Director Todd Phillips previously confirmed the sequel was moving ahead in June under the title Joker: Folie √† Deux, which literally translates to ‚Äúmadness for two.‚Äù Joaquin Phoenix, who won the Oscar for Best Actor for his portrayal of the character in the first movie, is expected to return for the sequel, Variety reports, while Lady Gaga is reportedly in talks to star alongside him, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The speculation is that Gaga may play Joker‚Äôs long-standing partner Harley Quinn (previously played by Margot Robbie in the DCEU), and that Gaga‚Äôs potential involvement could even lead the film to incorporate more... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: You will not do it later (most likely) - I'm a procrastinator, I know
entry.summary:
If you're like me, a big ass procrastinator, I'm sure you have said "I will do that later" to yourself before, right?
How many times times have you come back and done it? I'm guessing not that many times. If you do, congrats you're not a compulsive procrastinator! In my case, and probably quite a few people, we don't go back. At least not in a short amount of time. We might come back in a week or two, a couple of months, or even years after. Take this example, you've been working on a new feature. You finish it, do a refactoring pass, add a couple more tests to cover all cases and you've got just adding a couple of doc comments or writing documentation for this particular feature. You are tired and just want to finish the tasks, so you say to yourself "I will do that tomorrow" or "I wi‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to Govern Terraform States Using GitLab Enterprise?
entry.summary: TL;DR: With the mass adoption of Terraform and becoming the de facto tool for developers to build, and manage their cloud infrastructure at scale, most companies today, who rely heavily on Terraform for their infrastructure management, choose to do so with an orchestration tool. In this blog, we'll review the way to govern Terraform States using Gitlab Enterprise Terraform has become the nearly ubiquitous way to provision services in a cloud native era. However, when we start to build our infrastructure using Terraform‚Äôs as-code approach, there are a few things we need to consider in order to be able to manage these operations at scale, for a diversity of decentralized services, and for distributed teams. At Firefly, we often encounter the challenges of managing IaC at scale, as part of ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The story of a Noob
entry.summary: The stack ‚Äî VB6, Macros, MS Access Like I stated in the prologue, I was fascinated with tech from a very young age. What I failed to mention before is that thanks to my loving and understanding parents, my curiosity was not killed in school. That‚Äôs mostly thanks to the fact that in my house I could always take any ‚Äújunk‚Äù home to take apart and learn how it ticks. At the age of 13, I was already pretty good on a PC, but haven‚Äôt really dived into programming yet. My first real time was when I went to a few VB6 classes and convinced my parents to buy me a book. For me it was like magic, I could tell the computer what to do and it would do it, as long as I didn‚Äôt fuck it up somehow (which happened a lot at that time). I wrote small dumb things, what most would call a ‚ÄúHello World‚Äù. It was arou‚Ä¶

entry.title: Prologue ‚Äî One devs journey
entry.summary:
A brief history
It‚Äôs rude not to introduce myself, so I‚Äôll start with a little background, just to get us started. I can call myself a developer for over 15 years now, and a tinkerer for a few more. I started playing with technology from the very young age of 7, when I entered and won a race event where I built a toy solar car. Till today, as a system architect and having some successes (and failures) at tech startups, and running my own dev & consulting business. As of late, my team and I have released the first of our libraries as open source, this has made me look back at the path that led me here. My main goal is to share that story, the ups and downs (and sometimes sideways) and hopefully it will help someone on their path. I can‚Äôt promise it will be interesting all the time (or even pretty), but I hope you will join me for the journey. I will be writing this as a few different posts, each one not much longer than this one, as I want it to be a quick and fun read. So this is the plan: The story of a Noob ‚Äî My somewhat humble beginnings The journey begins ‚Äî Teaching myself in the age before google They don‚Äôt call it intelligence for nothing ‚Äî My military career School can‚Äôt teach you everything ‚Äî My time at Uni and my first freelance work It‚Äôs time to settle down ‚Äî My first real job Good code is like an onion, it has layers ‚Äî The right way to write code My eureka moment ‚Äî After writing the same code over and over, something had to change It‚Äôs ALIVE ‚Äî My solution to CRUD boilerplate, and the evolution of the layers Shit just got real ‚Äî Using what I learned to land a big contract Time to give back ‚Äî The birth of my first open source

entry.title: Next.js + Playwright + GitHub Actions Boilerplate
entry.summary: A comprehensive Todo app with APIs and E2E tests with GitHub Actions enabled. See the repository: https://github.com/burakkantarci/playwright-todo-app This project is a boilerplate to demonstrate the usage of modern stacks together. The project stack: Next.js Todo App Playwright GitHub Actions Foresight The tech stack market is expanding more and more and seeing everything in action is the easiest way to see the benefits. I decided to create a combination of Next.js, Playwright, GitHub Actions, and Foresight to create an E2E stack for a web application. All the external tooling is free; therefore, you don‚Äôt need to pay anything to try this stack. What will be the result A Serverless Next.js based TODO application with Upstash, the simplest way of production ready web application. Playwri‚Ä¶

entry.title: The need for social interaction
entry.summary: This is an opinionated article on the need for social interaction. The other day I got a message from Sandro, telling me he's in The Netherlands and asking if we could meet for a coffee. I'm always up for a coffee, so let's do it. I took the train from my town to Amsterdam, which is roughly 2.5 hours of travel. During this time you see so many people. And most of them are in their little bubble, their minds in different worlds, listening to a podcast, music, or watching a series. You'd even think they wouldn't notice it if you decide to enter the train fully naked. (I didn't try that) Arrive in Amsterdam. You quickly notice the same behavior. Everyone is walking around with AirPods, overhead earphones, and just zoning out. The interesting part is that you even see it with groups of people ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Noox.world ‚Äî Create, prove, and mint your on-chain achievements
entry.summary:
https://noox.world/) is a platform where you can create, prove, and mint on-chain achievements as soulbound NFTs. These NFTs are non-transferable and hold within their metadata the record of one‚Äôs on-chain actions.
ü§î¬†Problem & Solution:
Web3 projects all have a problem with user retention. To put it differently, purely financialized instruments are not the best incentive structure to allow for the creation of a robust and sustainable ecosystem.
Traditionally, achievements are included within game designs to provide gamers with the impetus to do more than simply complete the game. It is used to motivate players to maximize their own general score and let players obtain recognition for their performance via scores or ranks. A similar design can be applied to crypto and Web3. By unlocking‚Ä¶

entry.title: Aworker ‚Äî Web3 jobs
entry.summary:
‚Äú Hey Huntersüëã‚Ä®
I built a web3 job board where people can find remote jobs in web3 companies.
One more job board?
Probably.
I really do like this space. In my previous project (an NFT portfolio management tool), we got hundreds of requests from people who wanted to work there. And we didn‚Äôt do listings on other job boards. So, I wanted to build platform where people know more about this space and find new opportunities to work in the web3 companies.
Also, people will be able to get tokens while they are searching for a job.
Will be glad to hear your feedback and ideas.
P.S. Special offer for PH: Jobs listing for web3 companies is free for the next 3 days üòÄ¬† ‚Äù

entry.title: 3 ways to take screenshots on Linux
entry.summary:
3 ways to take screenshots on Linux Jim Hall Thu, 08/04/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this When writing about open source software, I prefer to show a few screenshots to help demonstrate what I'm talking about. As the old saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words. If you can show a thing, that's often better than merely trying to describe it. There are a few ways you can take screenshots in Linux. Here are three methods I use to capture screenshots on Linux: 1. GNOME GNOME has a great built-in screenshot tool. Just hit the PrtScr key on your keyboard, and GNOME displays a screenshot dialog:
Image by: (Jim Hall, CC BY-SA 40) The default action is to grab a screenshot of a region. This is an incredibly useful way to crop a screenshot as you mak‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lengthen the life of your hardware with Linux
entry.summary:
Lengthen the life of your hardware with Linux Don Watkins Thu, 08/04/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this Sustainability is an increasingly important problem when it comes to computing. Reduce, reuse, recycle is a popular motto for environmentally responsible consumption, but applying that to your computer hardware can be challenging. Many proprietary operating systems essentially force a hardware upgrade upon you long before your old hardware is used up. If you own a computer with Windows, you've probably needed to purchase a new one to upgrade because your old one didn't meet the hardware requirements of the latest OS. Apple doesn't do any better, either. A MacBook Air I owned was essentially rendered obsolete by an upgrade to macOS Mojave in 2019. By contrast, I ru‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Rotom Phone is finally getting a second camera
entry.summary:
While a largely iterative upgrade, the new Rotom Phone gets a couple new features. | Image: The Pok√©mon Company
The Rotom Phone is getting a big upgrade. Following its introduction in the Galar region three years ago, the updated version of the smartphone-that‚Äôs-inhabited-by-a-Pok√©mon is finally making the jump from one back camera to two. The handset will soon be available in the new Paldea region as well. It‚Äôs difficult to tell exactly what kind the second lens is for ‚Äî all I can really see is that the main lens remains blue while the new second lens is black. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs enough information to make an informed guess about whether this new lens is a telephoto, an ultrawide, or something else, though I‚Äôm hoping I‚Äôll be able to use that second camera to take pictures of the new best boy Fidough. Good to see Rotom Phone got the second... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: You can now preorder the Steam Deck in Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Taiwan
entry.summary:
Photo by Vjeran Pavic / The Verge
Valve is expanding Steam Deck shipments to some regions that could take the handheld PC-meets-console to new heights. The company just announced that reservations are now open in Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Taiwan through Komodo, a site that also sells Valve‚Äôs Index VR headset for PC among other games and gaming merchandise. If you visit steamdeck.com in one of those regions, you should be rerouted to Komodo‚Äôs site soon, or you can click here and select your language. Valve spokesperson Kaci Aitchison Boyle tells The Verge that the first batch of new reservations will be fulfilled later this year; a press release adds that shipments will begin in Japan, ‚Äúwith additional units planned to ship to customers in Korea, Hong Kong, and... entry.title: A leaked Tomb Raider script is looking pretty legit now that Square Enix DMCA‚Äôd it
entry.summary: Ever heard of the Streisand effect? It‚Äôs when someone tries to suppress information, only to wind up spreading it even further than it might have otherwise traveled. For example: Last week, I might have been skeptical if you told me a podcaster got their hands on a casting script for the next Tomb Raider game ‚Äî one which reveals that a older, lonely Lara Croft may dodge lasers in a ‚Äúgravity tomb‚Äù and engage in a romance with another female character. But if you also told me that the head lawyer at Tomb Raider studio Crystal Dynamics immediately sent a DMCA takedown notice ‚Äî one where he attested under penalty of perjury that the podcast infringed on the studio‚Äôs intellectual property ‚Äî I would absolutely think that script and those... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: One of the most enduring shows on TV is getting put behind a Peacock paywall
entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
NBC‚Äôs long-running soap opera Days of Our Lives will be leaving broadcast television after 57 years on to stream exclusively on Peacock, the network announced on Wednesday. The change means that fans who previously have been able to watch the show for free on broadcast will now have to pay for a streaming service to learn what happens next in the show‚Äôs fictional town of Salem. New episodes of Days of Our Lives will debut beginning September 12th. ‚ÄúWith a large percentage of the Days of Our Lives audience already watching digitally, this move enables us to build the show‚Äôs loyal fanbase on streaming while simultaneously bolstering the network daytime offering with an urgent, live programming opportunity for partners and consumers,‚Äù ... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
Facebook is shutting down live shopping, its QVC-like livestream feature that lets creators broadcast and sell products to an audience (via TechCrunch). The feature will officially shut down on October 1st, and Facebook says it‚Äôs part of the company‚Äôs initiative to shift focus to Reels. ‚ÄúAs consumers‚Äô viewing behaviors are shifting to short-form video, we are shifting our focus to Reels on Facebook and Instagram, Meta‚Äôs short-form video product,‚Äù Facebook explains. Although live shopping‚Äôs going away on Facebook, it will still be available on Instagram. First rolled out in 2018 in Thailand, live shopping opens up another revenue stream for creators on Facebook. It lets influencers host their own live shopping sessions where they can show... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Spain bans setting the AC below 27 degrees Celsius
entry.summary:
At a press conference last week, Spain‚Äôs Prime Minister Pedro S√°nchez urged the country to conserve energy in every way possible, including taking off ties to stay cool. | Photo By Eduardo Parra/Europa Press via Getty Images
As Europe grapples with a scorching summer and skyrocketing energy prices, Spain has become the latest government to tell its citizens to turn down the AC. A decree published on Tuesday morning in the official state gazette and scheduled to go into effect next week mandates that air conditioning in public places be set at or above 27 degrees Celsius (about 80 degrees Fahrenheit) and that doors of those buildings remain closed to save energy. Those public places include offices, shops, bars, theaters, airports, and train stations. The decree is being extended as a recommendation to all Spanish households. The rules include maintaining heating at or below 19 degrees Celsius (about 66 degrees Fahrenheit) in the winter and will remain in... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lucid Motors will barely make any EVs this year as it slashes production goals again
entry.summary:
Photo by Andrew Hawkins / The Verge
Luxury electric vehicle maker Lucid Motors is slashing its production forecast for 2022 for the second time this year. The Newark, California-based company announced it was revising its production expectations to between 6,000 and 7,000 vehicles. Lucid originally said it would make 20,000 vehicles in 2022, but that number was revised in February to 12,000‚Äì14,000 vehicles. It was another disappointing turn for the EV maker, which is strongly angling to capture some of Tesla‚Äôs market share with its ultra-premium, ultra-long-range Lucid Air sedan. Last quarter, Lucid announced a 10 percent price increase for the single model it has in production. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve identified the primary bottlenecks‚Äù ‚ÄúOur revised production guidance reflects the... Â§öÂπ¥Êù•ÔºåÊàë‰∏ÄÁõ¥‰ΩøÁî® Postfix Êù•ËææÂà∞Ëøô‰∫õÁõÆÁöÑ„ÄÇÂÆÉÂÖ∑ÊúâÂèØÊé•ÂèóÁöÑÁÆÄÂçïÈÖçÁΩÆ„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊúÄËøëÊàëÂºÄÂßãÂñúÊ¨¢ VPNÔºàmullvadÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Áü•ÈÅìÁöÑËØùÔºâÔºåËÄåÂú®¬†/etc/resolv.conf¬†ÂèëÁîüÂèòÂåñÊó∂‰ºöÂèòÂæóÊ∑∑‰π±Ôºà‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºå‰Ω†Âú® Postfix ÁöÑÊúçÂä°ÂêØÂä®ÂêéÊâçÂêØÂä® VPNÔºâ„ÄÇÊàëÊâæÂà∞‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏ÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÊõø‰ª£ÊñπÊ°àÔºöOpenSMTPD„ÄÇ
ÂÅáËÆæÊàëÊÉ≥Âú®‰ΩøÁî®¬†jao@gnu.org¬†ÂèëÈÄÅÁîµÂ≠êÈÇÆ‰ª∂Êó∂‰ΩøÁî® SMTP ÊúçÂä°Âô®¬†fencepost.gnu.orgÔºåËÄåÂú®ÊàëÁöÑ¬†From¬†Â§¥‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®¬†mail@jao.io¬†Êàñ¬†news@xmobar.org¬†Êó∂‰ΩøÁî®¬†smtp.jao.io„ÄÇOpenSMTPD ËÆ©‰Ω†ÈÄöËøá‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏ÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂¬†/etc/smtpd.conf¬†Êù•ÂÆûÁé∞Ôºö
ÔºàËøôÊòØÊàëÁöÑ Debian Êú∫Âô®‰∏≠ÁöÑÈªòËÆ§ÈÖçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÂè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊµÅË°åÁöÑÊõø‰ª£ÊñπÊ°àÊòØ¬†/etc/openstmpd.confÔºâ„ÄÇ
table aliases file:/etc/aliases table secrets db:/etc/mail/secrets.db
table sendergnu { jao@gnu.org } table senderjao { mail@jao.io, news@xmobar.org }
listen on localhost
action "local" mbox alias <aliases> action "relaygnu" relay host smtp+tls://gnu@fencepost.gnu.org:587 auth <secrets> action "relayjao" relay host smtps://jao@smtp.jao.io:465 auth <secrets>
match for local action "local" match for any from mail-from <sendergnu> action "relaygnu" match for any from mail-from <senderjao> action "relaygan"
Êàë‰ª¨Ëøò‰∏∫Ê≠§ÈÖçÁΩÆ‰∫ÜÊú¨Âú∞ÊäïÈÄí„ÄÇËøôÊòØÂÆåÊï¥ÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂ÔºÅÂîØ‰∏ÄÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÂè¶‰∏Ä‰ª∂‰∫ãÊòØÁîüÊàê¬†secrets.db¬†Êñá‰ª∂ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÂåÖÂê´‰∏éÈîÆ¬†gnu¬†Âíå¬†jao¬†ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÂíåÂØÜÁ†ÅÔºàËøô‰∫õÂè™ÊòØ‰ªªÊÑèÂêçÁß∞Ôºâ„ÄÇ‰∏∫Ê≠§ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Á∫ØÊñáÊú¨Êñá‰ª∂Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ÂΩ¢Âºè‰∏∫¬†<key> <user>:<password>¬†ÁöÑÊù°ÁõÆÔºö
gnu jao:my fencepost password jao mail@jao.io:xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
fencepost.gnu.org¬†Áî®Êà∑ÊòØ¬†jaoÔºåsmtp.jao.io¬†ÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÊòØ¬†mail@jao.ioÔºà‰Ω†ÁúãÔºå‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅËΩ¨‰πâÁ©∫Ê†ºÊàñ atsÔºâ„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂêéÊàë‰ª¨‰ΩøÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è¬†makemap¬†Êù•ÂàõÂª∫ÂØÜÈí•Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÔºö

entry.title: A sysadmin's guide to network interface configuration files
entry.summary:
A sysadmin's guide to network interface configuration files David Both Wed, 08/03/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this In the first article of this series, Get started with NetworkManager on Linux,¬†I looked at what NetworkManager does and some of the tools it provides for viewing network connections and devices. I discussed using the nmcli command to view the status of network devices and connections on a host. I also mentioned that NetworkManager does not need interface configuration files for most hosts. However, it can create its own INI-style connection configuration files, and it recognizes the older and now deprecated network interface configuration files. This article explores three questions: Why do I not use interface configuration files? Why do I use interfa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Axentix 2.0 ‚Äî Framework leaving the design choice to the developer
entry.summary:
Why Axentix
After using a lot of different frameworks and never be satisfied using them, Axentix has been created. The main goal is to give optionable & customizable components and let the design choice to the developer using the utility classes. All this has been made while making it the most easy to learn and with 0 dependencies.
What's new
üé® Customization enhancement: Add your own color to the palette and its 9 variants will be generated. Every component comes with CSS Variables making you able to custom each of them.
üë®‚Äçüéì Fast to learn, read and write : Axentix's class names are easy to read, write and learn. If you already used another framework, you already know a plenty of them.
üöÄ A lot of new components: Featuring waves, skeleton loading, theme switcher & dark mode handling...
üåà New design trends: Neumorphism, claymorphism & glassmorphism design are already integrated in Axentix !
Future
The future of the framework depends on the community and your advices and feature requests ! Feel free to ask for any help, request or feedback. ‚Äù

entry.title: Open source SAML SSO (by BoxyHQ) ‚Äî Integrate enterprise SSO with just a few lines of code
entry.summary:
https://boxyhq.com/)
We‚Äôre excited to see our vision to pioneer enterprise readiness come to life with our first product, SAML Jackson.
ü§îProblem:
Enterprise customers demand a certain level of security with their services. One of these is SAML authentication so they can manage access using their own permissions.
The problem with this is that building a SAML integration takes a long time and you need to build an integration for each of your customer's identity providers (IdP). This takes your team's focus away from your core product and requires a lot of resources.
üí°Solution:
SAML Jackson by BoxyHQ removes the pain of enterprise readiness by offering an out-of-the-box solution for deploying SAML quickly and efficiently. All you need to do is connect your product to BoxyHQ and we manage everything else for you. As if that was not enough, we connect to almost every IdP so you can go from the first line of code to fully support SAML in as little as a week!
Key features: ü§ù Integrate SAML using your favorite OAuth 2.0 or OpenID Connect libraries üî® Single integration with an instant connection to most IdPs ‚òëÔ∏è Open-source üñ•Ô∏è Admin UI to ease your customer support issues around SAML setup üé® Custom support and advice on your setup üìù Extensive documentation
üí¨ Feedback SAML Jackson is now live, and we‚Äôre looking forward to your thoughts and feedback, The team will be available to answer any questions you may have üôå ‚Äù

entry.title: How I use the Linux sed command to automate file edits
entry.summary:
How I use the Linux sed command to automate file edits Jim Hall Tue, 08/02/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this When I use the Linux command line, whether I'm writing a new program on my desktop computer or managing a website on my web server, I often need to process text files. Linux provides powerful tools that I leverage to get my work done. I frequently use sed, an editor that can modify text according to a pattern. sed stands for stream editor, and it edits text in a file and prints the results. One way to use sed is to identify several occurrences of one string in a file and replace them with a different string. You can use sed to process text files to a seemingly endless degree, but I'd like to share a few ways I use sed to help me manage files. Search and repl‚Ä¶

entry.title: How I disabled IPv6 on Linux
entry.summary:
How I disabled IPv6 on Linux David Both Mon, 08/01/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this IPv6 is a good thing for the Internet in general, but I find it unnecessarily complex for use in most home and small- to medium-size businesses. Like many others, I continue to use private IPv4 address ranges for my own internal networks and those for which I have some level of responsibility. My ISP only provides IPv4 addresses anyway, so it makes no sense to use IPv6 internally when all external packets are IPv4. Besides, IPv4 is much simpler, and one of my Linux Philosophy tenets is "Find the Simplicity." As a result, I disabled IPv6 on all my hosts. It seemed easy‚Äîat first. Here is how I did it.
More Linux resources Linux commands cheat sheet Advanced Linux commands cheat shee‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why program management matters in open source
entry.summary:
Why program management matters in open source Ben Cotton Mon, 08/01/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this Everyone does program management. Some just do it poorly. I've used that line for a laugh at the beginning of talks, but it's true. Program management is, at its core, the act of coordinating the interfaces between teams to produce something of value. In open source projects, the "something of value" is generally the software that the community produces. Most open source communities create software, and almost none of them have a formal program manager. So why have a program manager? The difference lies in managing the software development with intent instead of by accident. The smaller the community, the easier it is to self-coordinate. The need for intentional co‚Ä¶

entry.title: Learn Rust by debugging Rust
entry.summary:
Learn Rust by debugging Rust Gaurav Kamathe Fri, 07/29/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this In my previous¬†article about rustup, I showed you how to install the Rust toolchain. Well, what good is the toolchain if you won‚Äôt be using it to get more hands-on with Rust? Learning any language involves reading existing code and writing a lot of sample programs. That's a good way to become proficient in a language. However, there's a third way: debugging code. Learning through debugging involves trying to compile a pre-written (buggy) sample program, understanding the errors generated by the compiler, fixing the sample code, and then re-compiling it. Repeat that process until the code successfully compiles and runs. Rustlings is an open source project by the Rust team that h‚Ä¶

entry.title: Fix bugs in Bash scripts by printing a stack trace
entry.summary:
Fix bugs in Bash scripts by printing a stack trace Evan "Hippy" Slatis Fri, 07/29/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this No one wants to write bad code, but inevitably bugs will be created. Most modern languages like Java, JavaScript, Python, etc., automatically print a stack trace when they encounter an unhandled exception, but not shell scripts. It would make it much easier to find and fix bugs in shell scripts if you could print a stack trace, and, with a little work, you can. Shell scripts can span multiple files, and well-written code is further broken down into functions. Tracing issues when something goes wrong in a shell script can be difficult when these scripts get large enough. A stack trace that walks the code backward from the error to the beginning can sho‚Ä¶

entry.title: Casama ‚Äî Share your crypto trading ideas, invest together in minutes
entry.summary:
@gerwin_fricke, @slava_tschurilin & @moritz_lochner here ‚Äì we‚Äôre super excited to launch Casama:
üí∞ What is Casama? Casama lets you create crypto trade positions that can be funded and executed as a group in minutes ‚Äì no browser extensions, no complex settings. So you can share trading ideas with your friends and get a management fee if it performs well.
üî• Why did we start Casama? Have you ever posted a trading idea in a group chat without actually ever acting on it? As crypto natives, we want to move fast on good trades. Instead of having vague discussions, back and forth decisions and potentially out on alpha üò±
That's why we built Casama ‚Äì to decide on actionable trades together with skin in the game.
üß≠ So far we‚Äôve built: - Wizard to deploy investment pools with custom settings - Simple web-based wallet to interact with pools - Top-up via PayPal to convert fiat ($) to stablecoin (USDC) - Swapping integration to buy and trade tokens
‚ö°Ô∏è Inviting friends and pooling funds in minutes ‚Äì how is it possible?
That‚Äôs right, invite your friends and pool funds as easy as starting a group chat and paying with PayPal. We conceal complex hashes and automate all the tedious transactions so you don't have to do them.
üôè Your feedback is gold to us ‚Äì please share any questions, ideas and comments below. We're just kicking things off and would love hear from fellow makers! The team (of currently 5) is working heads down to improve the UX and features based on your input. Finally, the first 50 deposits get $20 for depositing $10!
Website: https://www.casama.io/ ‚Äù

entry.title: OpenBB Bot ‚Äî Investment research with the community has never been easier
entry.summary:
openbb.co/products/bot
From being an open source company, we understand the value that customization brings to users. Thus, it has been a priority for us when developing OpenBB Bot. This can be seen from the charts which can be customizable to show your preferred technical analysis indicators or from the fact that you can set your own alerts when your asset of choice hits a certain value.
Note that the OpenBB Bot was built on top of the famous OptionsFamBot which can reach over 1 Million users already, and on top of GamestonkTerminal Bot.
Let us know what sort of data you are interested in seeing, and we can prioritize accordingly.
Are you a server owner on Discord? Get started with OpenBB Bot today: openbb.co/bot-discord
Investment research for everyone, anywhere. ‚Äù

entry.title: Use this nifty Unix tool to process text on Linux
entry.summary:
Use this nifty Unix tool to process text on Linux Jim Hall Thu, 07/28/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this Unix has always excelled at processing text, and Linux is no different. And the tools to work with and transform text files still exist on all Linux systems. Like other computer systems, early Unix printed on paper, using a typewriter-style printing device. These printers provided limited formatting options, but with clever application of Unix tools, you could prepare professional-looking documents. One such tool was the pr tool, to prepare text documents for printing. Let's explore how to use standard Unix tools, such as the pr processor and the fmt text formatter, to prepare text files for printing on a typewriter-style printer. [ Read also:¬†How I use the Linux‚Ä¶

entry.title: How I manage files from the Linux command line
entry.summary:
How I manage files from the Linux command line Jim Hall Wed, 07/27/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this Managing files in a graphical desktop like GNOME or KDE is an exercise in point-and-click. To move a file into a folder, you click and drag the icon to its new home. To remove a file, you drag it into the ‚ÄúTrash‚Äù icon. The graphical interface makes desktop computing easy to use. But we don't always interact with Linux systems with a graphical interface. If you work on a server, you likely need to use the command line to get around. Even desktop users like me might prefer to interact with their system through a terminal and command line. I tend to rely on a few commands to manage my files from the command line: List files with Linux ls For anyone who uses the command‚Ä¶
